awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Learning to solve problems in context-rich environments: A naturalistic study in STEM workplaces, research labs, project-based courses and lab courses
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER project investigates learning and assessment of problem-solving in context-rich settings, such as research laboratories, project-based courses, and STEM workplaces.  It includes an education plan focused on transferring the research to improve education.  Because these context-rich, problem-solving experiences more closely mimic professional work, they offer important venues for STEM workforce development. However, these environments tend to be resource and time-intensive compared to lecture courses, so it is important to understand their unique benefits. The level of "context" refers to the complexity of the goals, tools, and applications for learning. While there is a substantial amount of education research related to lower-context learning, such as active learning in lecture courses emphasizing knowing, concepts, and the acquisition of knowledge, there has been less education research on high context ("context-rich") environments. such as laboratories and actual research experiences that involve practice.  The project will support the improvement of context-rich experiences that develop the science and engineering workforce, support retention and diversity, create free and publicly available assessments for STEM faculty, and guide policies on expanding and improving access to research experiences and other context-rich environments.  The project addresses a national need for research that can inform the development, testing, validation, and dissemination of assessments of learning in context-rich environments and guide education policy.

This research will examine how context-rich experiences prepare students for STEM workforce careers.   The research plan involves describing the experience, observing evidence for learning, comparisons of activities, outcomes, and the development of new assessments.  The conceptual framework is based on applying Cultural Historical Activity Theory (CHAT) to learning in context-rich settings.  CHAT provides a perspective that situates cognition within an activity system that relates a subject, an objective, and a community as an activity system that accomplishes practical outcomes. Data collection and analysis will utilize Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT), particularly to understand mechanisms and factors within context-rich problem-solving environments that support outcomes such as development of professional identity, self-efficacy, and persistence.  The education plan involves a project based first-year physics course, as well as the development of a set of validated tools that could be used for the assessment of learning in context-rich environments.  Thus, the education plan is integrated with the research activities and would provide both local (course-specific) and transferable (disseminated) outcomes.  

The CAREER program is a National Science Foundation (NSF)-wide activity that offers awards in support of junior faculty who exemplify the role of teacher-scholars through outstanding research, excellent education, and the integration of education and research within the context of the mission of their organizations. This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program.  ECR supports fundamental research that advances knowledge on STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied learning within context-rich environments where scientists and engineers collaboratively work on complex problems using a variety of tools. Although the original plan was significantly impacted by the COVID pandemic there were several impactful outcomes across four main areas. 

First, significant work was done to study students' learning and growth within undergraduate research experiences. We studied factors contributing to students' growth in sense of belonging within the research lab, identity as a scientist, and self-confidence as a researcher, which resulted in a theoretical model included as a diagram with the project outcomes. We also examined metacognition (how students reflect on their own understanding) and how they seek or avoid help when confronted with obstacles during their research. Further, we looked specifically at challenges and benefits of remote research experiences, including an approach to assessing learning in research projects using concept maps. 

Our second area examined the expert practices of theoretical physicists when they are involved in long and challenging projects. This work revealed different phases of their theoretical work that are often not captured by the shorter problems and assignments given in theoretical physics courses. Specifically, we focused on how theorists generate new ideas and questions, how they use analogies and assumptions in their work, and how they use highly simplified mathematical models toward the beginning of a project to examine feasibility. One figure from this project is included to show the four main phases of the theoretical research process. This research suggests new types of activities that would introduce students to a broader range of problem-solving practices. 

A third major area of research focused on understanding factors that shape the career interests and decisions of undergraduate physics majors, particularly their post-baccalaureate plans. This research involved studying how students develop interests in particular subfields of physics (e.g., astronomy, biophysics, nuclear physics) or particular methods of doing physics (i.e., with theoretical math, with computational models, or with laboratory experiments). Our research shows that many students enter physics because of an initial fascination with astronomy, but have little awareness of other subfields of physics. The standard undergraduate physics curriculum does little to introduce students to modern subfields of physics. The highest impact experiences were research opportunities and elective courses that aligned with the subfield. Unfortunately, both of these mechanisms depend on students having access to research opportunities and specialized coursework, which may not be the case at many institutions. Our work has set the stage for the development of new assessments of career interest formation. 

The final major area involved impacting undergraduate teaching at Rochester Institute of Technology, particularly through the introduction of more project-based learning in the undergraduate physics curriculum. Collaborative, project-based learning experiences were incorporated into three courses for physics majors in their first and second years. In all cases, these were multi-week final projects that involved computation or laboratory work. The projects incorporated a wide range of skills and abilities, including project management, and connected the course content to students' own interests. 

Regarding professional development for the PI and his research group, they developed new skills in cognitive task analysis, which involves highly structured interviews and analysis to capture how people think through a process. Also, the team learned to apply Activity Theory to holistically considering how social interactions, tools (e.g., computers, lab equipment, mathematics), and goals affect how individuals or teams solve problems. Finally, the career decision-making work deepened the teams knowledge of Social Cognitive Career Theory and other models for interest formation and decision-making. 

Over the duration of the project, one postdoc, one PhD student, and 20 undergraduates contributed to the research and gained valuable professional development experiences. The postdoc and PhD student were lead authors on multiple papers, eight undergraduates presented their work at national conferences, and five senior theses resulted from this project.
